title: Developing an Integrated Strategic Counterterrorism Communications Initiative and Establishing a Temporary Organization to Support Certain Government-wide Communications Activities Directed Abroad

enrichment.summary: This executive order establishes a government-wide initiative to coordinate and improve public communications aimed at countering terrorist organizations, especially al-Qa'ida, by targeting audiences abroad with strategic messaging to reduce radicalization. It creates a Center for Strategic Counterterrorism Communications to lead these efforts and a temporary support office within the State Department to assist agencies in implementing focused communications campaigns.
potential_concerns: The strategic counterterrorism communications may inadvertently stigmatize Muslim populations abroad by associating them broadly with extremist ideologies, which could deepen alienation and hinder counter-radicalization efforts.

Messaging targeted at foreign nationals might be perceived as propaganda, reducing the credibility of U.S. diplomatic efforts and potentially harming U.S. relations with citizens of specific countries targeted by the initiative.

Unintended backlash could arise if communications campaigns are viewed as interference in domestic affairs of foreign nations, complicating diplomatic relations and undermining global engagement goals.

Over-reliance on digital and social media tools might miss or alienate populations with limited internet access or media literacy, reducing the effectiveness of outreach to some foreign-national groups.
